Comment: You are wrong on both points. First the Supreme Court only has original jurisdiction in a narrow set of cases; in all other cases it only has appellate jurisdiction. Secondly, federal courts have the power to deputize anyone to enforce their rulings; all they need is to find someone will to go along with it.  Also, the Court is not going to issue rulings without a suit presented to it. Your doom and gloom is based on an inaccurate set of premises.
Author: AlexKingstonsGigolo

Comment: I think that in times like this (and it isn’t doom and gloom to hope that the highest court on the land would act for the rule of law) where an administration is break laws, not following judicial orders, that there is a point where direct intervention is needed. The SCOTUS also has a duty to the constitution.   If the military is given orders to directly go against the constitution, they have the power to defy those orders to protect it and the country. I would think that all law enforcement also would have some  mandate like this. In fact, qualified immunity for police is a thing.   The highest court in the land can interpret (and have) the laws to suit them. If it was pressing enough, I’m sure they could do as I’ve suggested. I can see what side you are on in this discussion tho.
